questions.text: The mother of a 12-year-old girl was worried that her daughter is shorter when compared with her classmates. On examination, the child had a webbed neck, low hairline, and shield chest. A provisional diagnosis of Turner's syndrome was made. Which of the following is a likely finding to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The likely finding seen in a patient with Turner syndrome is bilateral small streak ovaries.

Turner syndrome results from complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome. It is characterized by hypogonadism in phenotypic females. It is the most common sex chromosome abnormality in females. Three types of karyotypic abnormalities are seen

  • Missing an entire X chromosome - this results in a 45X karyotype.
  • Structural abnormalities of the X chromosomes - isochromosome of the long arm and loss of the short arm, 46X,i(X)(q10), deletion of portions of both long and short arms that lead to the formation of a ring chromosome, 46X,r(X), deletion of portions of the short or long arm, 46X,del(Xq) or 46X,del(Xp).
  • Mosaics - they will have 45X along with one or more karyotypically normal or abnormal cell types. Examples are 45X/46XX, 45X/46XY, 45X/47XXX, 45X/46X,i(X)(q10).

Important features associated with Turner's syndrome:

  • Short stature
  • Webbing of neck
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Cubitus valgus
  • Streak ovaries
  • Infertility, amenorrhea
  • Peripheral lymphedema at birth
  • Low posterior hairline
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Pigmented nevi
  • Coarctation of aorta

There is failure to develop normal secondary sex characteristics at puberty. The genitalia remain infantile, breast development is inadequate, and there is little pubic hair. Short stature and amenorrhea are of particular importance in establishing the diagnosis in an adult.

Other options:

Aortic dissection, subluxation of lens, and mitral valve prolapse are seen in Marfan syndrome.

questions.text: A teacher demonstrated the steps of handwashing to her students. Students also performed the same activity later at school and at home. What is the type of learning in this case?
questions.solution:
The type of learning seen in this case is psychomotor learning.

The psychomotor domain includes learning by observation, physical movements, and the usage of motor skill areas of the brain. The development of these skills requires practice, depending upon the complexity of the task. It is measured based on speed, precision, distance, and procedures in execution.

The three domains in learning are the cognitive, psychomotor, and affective domains. They are described as follows.

Cognitive learning includes the domain of knowledge. Bloom's taxonomy described six levels of cognitive skills. This was revised to include types of knowledge and cognitive processes. The cognitive processes include remembering, understanding, applying, analyzing, evaluating, and creating. Eg. Solving multiple-choice questions in the NEET PG entrance exam involves the usage of the cognitive domain. 

Psychomotor learning includes the domain of skills. It includes imitation, manipulation, precision, articulation, and naturalization. Eg. Learning how to insert an IV cannula by observing the residents and nurses during the internship involves the usage of the psychomotor domain.

Affective learning includes the domain of attitude and values. It includes receiving, responding, valuing, organizing, and characterization by value. Eg. Communicating with patients with empathy, responding to their concerns, and interacting with the relatives of patients involves the usage of the affective domain.

Integration of all these three methods in teaching and learning methodology leads to a better understanding of the subject.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with AIDS presented with fever and productive cough. On auscultation, bronchial breath sounds and crepitations were heard in the right infra-scapular region. Chest X-ray showed right lower lobe consolidation. The CD4 count was 55 cells/mm3. What is the most common causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of productive cough with fever, bronchial breath sounds and crepitations on auscultation along with lower lobe consolidation on chest X-ray point towards the diagnosis of lobar pneumonia.

The most common causative organism is Streptococcus pneumonia, irrespective of HIV status. In AIDS patients, opportunistic infection-causing bacterial pneumonia occurs at any clinical stage and at any CD4 cell count. Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia would present with dry cough and interstitial infiltrates on chest x-ray (option A).

Patients with pneumococcal (lobar) pneumonia present with fever, dyspnea, and productive cough. On examination, involved lobes are dull to percussion, bronchial breath sounds, and crackles are heard on auscultation.

A chest radiograph reveals focal, segmental, or lobar consolidation of involved lobes.

Other options:

Option A:

Pneumocystis jiroveci causes pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) in AIDS patients with CD4 counts below 200 cells/mm3.

PCP presents with fever, dry cough, and dyspnea. Inspiratory crackles are heard on auscultation. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral, symmetric, interstitial infiltration. Initially, infiltrates are perihilar, as the disease progress, it becomes diffuse.

The chest radiographs given below show ground-glass opacities in PCP

Option C: 

Staphylococcus aureus causes bacterial pneumonia with features similar to pneumococcal pneumonia. The differentiating feature is that chest X-ray in Staph. aureus infection shows pneumatoceles (cavitation).

The X-ray shows pneumatoceles (air-filled cysts within lung parenchyma).

Option D: Mycoplasma causes atypical pneumonia. Patients present with dry cough, fever, chills, malaise, and upper respiratory tract symptoms. On auscultation, wheezes or rales are heard. Chest X-ray shows peribronchial pneumonia with prominent bronchial markings, interstitial infiltration, and atelectasis.

The chest X-ray below shows patchy consolidation at the hilum and fanning to the periphery

questions.text: A patient presents with a seizure. On evaluation, urine osmolality is 1000 mOsm/Kg and serum osmolality is 270 mOsm/Kg. Which electrolyte abnormality can be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has high urine osmolality of 1000 mOsm/kg (normal 500-800 mOsm/kg) and low plasma osmolality of 270 mOsm/kg (normal 285-295 mOsm/kg). This is seen in the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone synthesis (SIADH) and hyponatremia is the most common electrolyte abnormality seen.

Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone ADH release (SIADH) is a condition where there is an unsuppressed release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) from the pituitary gland or nonpituitary sources or its continued action on vasopressin receptors.

ADH promotes the reabsorption of water from the collecting duct. Excessive secretion of ADH in SIADH results in enhanced water reabsorption. Therefore, only water is reabsorbed and not the solutes resulting in concentrated urine. This is depicted as high urine osmolality. The excess of water reabsorbed from the tubules expand and dilute the extracellular fluid leading to dilutional hyponatremia. This is depicted as low plasma osmolality. 

Since there is an increase in body water with little or no change in body sodium in SIADH, this is known as euvolemic hyponatremia.

Patients may be asymptomatic or present with headache, confusion, nausea, vomiting, anorexia, seizures, and coma.

questions.text: A primi at term presented with labor pain and multiple painful vesicular lesions on her vulva. No rashes were found on other parts of the body. What will be the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a primi in labor pain with multiple, painful vesicular lesions on her vulva is suggestive of an active herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. Management involves the administration of acyclovir and elective cesarean section.

HSV infection in pregnancy can be caused by either HSV-1 or HSV-2 and transmitted by sexual contact. The infection can be primary, nonprimary, first episode, and recurrent.  

HSV infection (both HSV 1 and 2) during pregnancy has a risk of vertical transmission of the infection to the fetus. The risk is higher in the primary than in the recurrent infection. The maximum risk of fetal infection is during labor, although it can occur in utero and post-natally from direct contact. 

Suspicious lesions should be sent for PCR testing or culture. Antiviral treatment with acyclovir should be given if found positive. Women with no active genital lesions, asymptomatic, or those with active lesions in non-genital areas can undergo normal labor and delivery. 

Management of HSV infection during pregnancy:

  • Oral acyclovir or valacyclovir for primary or recurrent infections during pregnancy.
  • IV acyclovir followed by oral acyclovir for severe or disseminated infection
  • Oral analgesics or topical anesthetics for pain relief
  • Catheterization for urinary retention

Cesarean delivery reduces the risk of vertical transmission during labor and is indicated in:

  • Cases of active genital lesions - both primary and recurrent
  • Prodromal symptoms like vulval itching or burning

Other options:

Option B: The presene of active lesions is a contraindication for induction of labor.

Option C: Spontaneous delivery is contraindicated in the presence of active lesions.

Option D: Even after treatment with acyclovir, normal delivery is not indicated owing to the risk of dormant viral transmission to the fetus.

questions.text: A young air-hostess presented to the outpatient department with dilated veins on her left leg (image). According to the CEAP classification for varicose veins, what will be the C stage in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image above shows dilated, tortuous veins of the lower limb. In asymptomatic patients, they are classified as C2A according to the Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology (CEAP) classification for chronic venous disorders.

Varicose veins are characterized by the tortuous dilatation of subcutaneous veins resulting from venous insufficiency. Patients have heaviness, burning, and aching over the affected area or whole limb, which increases throughout the day or on prolonged standing. Compression and elevation can relieve the symptoms.

Diagnosed by duplex ultrasound and is treated by modalities such as compression, laser ablation, radiofrequency ablation, endovenous glue, ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy, and open surgery.

Image A shows tortuous dilated veins (C2), Image B is atrophie blanche (C4b), and Image C shows fan-shaped telangiectasia (C4c).

questions.text: A 30-year-old married woman came for an infertility evaluation. On performing further investigations, intramural fibroids of sizes 7x5cm and 5x3cm were seen at the right and left cornual ends of the uterus. Her husband's semen analysis was found to be normal. What is the appropriate management of this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for a woman with infertility due to intramural fibroids at both the cornual ends of the uterus is myomectomy. The infertility, in this case, is due to the fibroids blocking the right and left cornua of the uterus.

Myomectomy refers to the removal of fibroids and preserving the uterus. It is indicated in women presenting with infertility, those who desire pregnancy, or those who wish to retain the uterus.

Intracavitary fibroids can be resected via the hysteroscopic approach, while subserosal or intramural fibroids require laparotomy or laparoscopic myomectomy.

Other options:

Option A: Uterine artery embolization is not done in this case, as it may decrease fertility, as a result of pelvic adhesions. It is a technique in which polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), gel foam particles, or metal coils are injected into the uterine arteries. This embolization reduces vascularity and the size of the fibroid. It is best suited to control menorrhagia in multiparous women.

Option C: Artificial reproductive techniques are not indicated in this case as infertility is seen to be due to the fibroids blocking the cornual ends of the uterus. However, it may be considered at a later stage.

Option D: GnRH analogs when used for 6 months, can reduce the tumor size by targeting the growth effects of estrogen and progesterone. It can be used in women with infertility caused by cornual fibroids. They are often used preoperatively to reduce the size of the fibroid and facilitate a hysteroscopic approach to surgery. However, it is expensive and can cause menopausal symptoms if used for >6 months. Fibroids are known to regrow 3-4 months after stopping the therapy. 

Related Pearl: Myomectomy

Myomectomy

  • Retains uterus and hence preserves childbearing function.
  • Effective for heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pressure.
  • Disadvantage - formation of new clones of abnormal myocytes.
  • Hysteroscopic myomectomy is the procedure of choice for removing intracavitary myomas.
  • Vaginal myomectomy is performed in case, a fibroid prolapses through the cervix.

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text: A male patient had feeble femoral pulses with upper-limb blood pressure of 186/90 mmHg. Chest X-ray showed enlarged intercostal arteries. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of hypertension in the upper limb, weak lower limb pulse, and enlarged intercostal arteries on chest X-ray are pointing towards the diagnosis of coarctation of the aorta.

Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital heart defect characterized by the narrowing of the thoracic aorta near the insertion of the ductus arteriosus. It is associated with the bicuspid aortic valve, atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect, mitral regurgitation, berry aneurysm, and Turner syndrome. It is more common in males.

Depending on the site of constriction it may be-

  • Preductal - constriction proximal to the ductus arteriosus. (infantile type)
  • Postductal - constriction distal to the ductus arteriosus (adult type).

Physical examination findings include-

  • Bounding upper limb pulses (radial, carotid) and weak lower limb pulses (femoral, popliteal, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis)
  • Increased Radio-femoral delay
  • Hypertension in upper limbs; hypotension in lower limbs
  • Difference in blood pressure of more than 20 mmHg between upper and lower limbs
  • Continuous machinery like murmur (due to collaterals) is heard over the scapula
  • Systolic ejection click and systolic ejection murmur in the left upper sternal border (due to bicuspid aortic valve)

Radiologically, the chest X-ray may reveal-

  • Figure 3 sign - Pathognomonic of coarctation of the aorta. Due to indentation of the aorta at the site of coarctation and pre and post-stenotic dilatation along the left paramediastinum. 
  • Notching of ribs  (Roesler's sign) due to inferior rib erosion by dilated intercostal collateral vessels. 
    • Collateral blood supply occurs from the arch of the aorta to the descending thoracic aorta bypassing the narrowed aorta.
    • It occurs via the arch of the aorta → internal thoracic artery → anterior intercostal artery → posterior intercostal artery → descending thoracic aorta.
    • 4th to 8th ribs are most commonly involved. 1st and 2nd ribs are spared as the intercostal arteries in these ribs do not communicate with the descending aorta.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is not compliant with spectacles for her myopic astigmatism. What would be the appropriate management in her case?
questions.solution:
The appropriate management for myopic astigmatism in a 15-year-old girl (<18 years) would be spherical equivalent spectacles.

Prescription in astigmatism has 3 components:

  • Power of the spherical component: Convex (+) or concave (-) in dioptre sphere (DS)
  • Power of the cylinder: Convex (+) or concave (-) dioptre cylinder (DC)
  • Axis or orientation of the cylinder¬†

The cylinder power and axis are correcting the astigmatic part of the refractive error. If an astigmatic eye were to be corrected with a spherical lens alone, the result would be a blur circle on the retina, called the circle of least confusion.

The spherical lens power places the circle of least confusion on the retina and is called the spherical equivalent.¬†It is defined as the spherical power whose focal point coincides with the circle of least confusion, where one would see minimal blurring in their vision. To calculate the spherical equivalent, add half the cylinder power to the sphere power:

Spherical equivalent= spherical power + 1/2 (cylindrical power)

For example, for spherical power +2 and cylindrical power +3,

+2.00 +(+3.00 /2) = +3.50.

Spherical equivalent spectacles are given if one has to give less cylinder power than was measured.

Other options:

Options A and C - LASIK and Femto LASIK should be done in patients above 18 years of age.

Option D - Implantable Collamer lens is indicated for patients 21-45 years of age.

The image demonstrates the steps of LASIK

questions.text: Which of the following is a formal thought disorder?
questions.solution:
Derailment is a formal thought disorder.

It is a breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of being goal-oriented. It is generally identified in schizophrenic patients as a generalized loosening of associations.

For example, a person with derailment thought disorder might jump from talking about rabbits to the hair on their head to your sweater. They talk in chains of semi-related ideas. Their communication style has a generalized loosening of associations. Their ideas often fall further and further from the topic. 

Formal thought disorders are:

  • Circumstantiality is the overinclusion of trivial or irrelevant details that impedes the sense of getting to the point.
  • Clang association is an association of thoughts with the sound of words rather than by their meaning (e.g., through rhyming).
  • Derailment is the breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.
  • Flight of ideas is a succession of multiple associations so that thoughts seem to move abruptly from idea to idea, through rapid, pressured speech.
  • Neologism is the invention of new words or phrases or the use of conventional words in idiosyncratic ways.
  • Perseveration is the repetition of out-of-context words, phrases, or ideas.
  • Tangentiality is responding to a question, that is appropriate to the general topic without actually answering the question. 
  • Thought blocking is a sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas.

Other options:

Option A - An obsession is a recurrent and intrusive thought, feeling, idea, or sensation.

Option C - A delusion is defined as a false belief based on incorrect inference about external reality that firmly sustains despite evidence to the contrary.

Option D - Thought insertion is a type of delusion where the patient believes that thoughts are not his/her own and have been inserted into his/her mind.

Controversial: The classification of OCD as a certain form of thought is debatable based on the resource. Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry (11th Edition) lists it under disorders of content of thought, whilst Fish's Clinical Psychopathology (4th Edition) mentions it under disorders of possession of thought.

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally"¬†

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud"¬†

¬†B.¬†Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

¬†
¬†DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
¬†DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of atherosclerosis underwent a circumflex artery bypass. The stent is now placed successfully. He is already taking lisinopril, verapamil, metoprolol. Which drug should be added?
questions.solution:
P2Y12 receptor blocker should be added to prevent stent thrombosis.

Clopidogrel, a P2Y12 receptor blocker, along with aspirin is called dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT).

DAPT should be continued for at least 1 year following stent placement to prevent stent thrombosis. After the recommended duration of treatment with dual antiplatelet therapy, aspirin should be continued indefinitely.

questions.text:
An alcoholic patient presented with severe abdominal pain. Pancreatitis was suspected and a CT scan revealed lesions with fluid collected near the body of the pancreas. Which of the following enzymes is most likely to be elevated in this scenario?

GGT- Gamma-glutamyltransferase

CEA- Carcinoembryonic antigen
questions.solution:
In an alcoholic patient with acute pancreatitis, serum lipase is the enzyme most likely to be elevated.

Acute pancreatitis is often caused by gallstones (70%) or alcoholism (25%). The cardinal symptom is acute-onset severe pain in the upper quadrant of the abdomen. The patient usually presents in shock (hypotension and tachycardia) and tachypnoea. Some may also present with signs of bleeding into the fascial planes leading to discoloration of the sites involved:

  1. Cullen’s sign: Around the umbilicus
  2. Grey Turner’s sign: Flanks
  3. Fox sign: Inguinal region
  4. Bryant’s sign: Scrotum

The diagnosis is often clinical with a laboratory diagnosis. Though serum amylase (>3 times) is indicative of pancreatitis, serum lipase is preferred over serum amylase as it is more sensitive and specific. Contrast-enhanced tomography (CECT) of the abdomen can be used to exclude pancreatitis if in doubt.

The severity of the acute pancreatitis is assessed using the Ranson and Glasgow scoring system ( ≥3 at 48h of onset of pain ). APACHE, SOFA, SAPS, and MODS can also be used to assess the severity of pancreatitis in intensive care (ICU) settings.  Pancreatitis is managed conservatively with initial nasogastric drainage followed by intravenous fluids, analgesia, and frequent monitoring of vital signs, urine output, and blood gases.

Other options:

Option A: Serum gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) can also be elevated. It is a biomarker for pancreatic disease and alcohol consumption but is not sensitive and specific to acute pancreatitis.

Option B: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), a tumor marker that is elevated in the adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

Option D: Elevated serum bilirubin is a result of (i) overproduction of bilirubin (E.g: hemolytic anemia) or (ii) impaired uptake by the liver (liver cirrhosis) or (iii) regurgitation of bilirubin (obstructive jaundice). It is not seen in acute pancreatitis.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Acute Pancreatitis

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign (A): Bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign (B): Bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Fox sign: Discolouration below the inguinal ligament
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): Dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

Related Pearl: Laboratory Findings in Acute Pancreatitis

  • Elevated serum amylase and serum lipase
    • Serum amylase level rises immediately and peaks in few hours and returns to normal in 3–5 days
    • Serum amylase level lacks specificity
    • Serum amylase levels do not correlate with the severity of pancreatitis.
    • Serum lipase is more specific, and it is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours later
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia, hypoalbuminemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Elevated serum levels of hepatic enzymes like alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
  • Azotemia, due to prerenal acute renal failure in case of severe fluid loss

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in Acute Pancreatitis

Radiographic findings of acute pancreatitis are non-specific.

The sentinel loop is seen in an X-ray. It is a focal area of adynamic ileus close to an intra-abdominal inflammatory process. A sentinel loop in the upper abdomen indicates pancreatitis.

The sentinel loop sign may aid in localizing the source of inflammation. For example, a sentinel loop in the upper abdomen may indicate pancreatitis, while one in the right lower quadrant may be due to appendicitis.

Colon cut-off sign: Functional spasm at the splenic flexure due to the extension of inflammation to phrenicocolic ligament via transverse mesocolon.

The X-ray given below shows sentinel loop sign (marked as '1') and colon cut-off sign (marked as '2') in a patient with acute pancreatitis:

 

Renal halo sign: Edema around the kidney due to the involvement of paranephric fat resulting in:

  • Obliteration of psoas shadow
  • Localised ground-glass appearance

questions.text: A patient presented with headache, vomiting, and fever. Meningitis was suspected. While performing a lumbar puncture, which is the last structure you will pierce just before entering the lumbar cistern?
questions.solution:
The arachnoid membrane is the last structure you will pierce while performing a lumbar puncture, just before entering the lumbar cistern.

Lumbar puncture is a diagnostic procedure done to obtain a sample of cerebrospinal fluid from the subarachnoid space. During the procedure, the following structures are pierced to reach the subarachnoid space, in the given order:

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous tissue
  • Supraspinous ligament
  • Interspinous ligament
  • Ligamentum flavum
  • Dura mater
  • Arachnoid membrane

Indications:

  • Diagnosis of suspected meningitis and subarachnoid hemorrhage 
  • Spinal anesthesia and intrathecal administration of antibiotics/chemotherapy
  • Therapeutic relief of pseudotumor cerebri, less frequently

Contraindications for lumbar puncture include:

  • Thrombocytopenia or other bleeding diatheses (including anticoagulant therapy)
  • Raised intracranial pressure
  • Spinal epidural abscess
  • Infection over the site

Site of the procedure:

In adults, the spinal cord ends at the level of the lower border of the L1 vertebra. Lumbar puncture is usually performed at L3-L4 space (below L1 vertebra) to avoid potential needle trauma to the spinal cord.

Technique:

The patient is usually placed in the lateral recumbent position. An alternative position is the sitting position, useful in obese patients to determine the midline. L3-L4 space is located by palpating the right and left posterior superior iliac crests and moving the fingers medially toward the spine at the same level.

A local anesthetic like 1% lidocaine is administered. A 22-gauge needle is advanced through the skin. In the lateral recumbent position, the bevel should face up, and in the sitting position, it should face to one side or the other, to avoid injury to the dural fibers. There is a loss of resistance as the needle enters the epidural space. Dura and then arachnoid are next pierced, to release CSF.

Complications following lumbar puncture:

Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) is a common post-procedure symptom. It occurs due to loss of CSF through the dura which causes traction on the pain-sensitive intracranial structures. The headache in PDPH is typically frontal or occipital. The smaller the needle used, the lesser the risk of PDPH.

Other complications include infections, bleeding, cerebral herniation, and radicular pain.

questions.text: A young girl presented to the OPD for examination. She is tall and thin with slender fingers, and dislocated lenses. Workup revealed cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency. Which amino acid supplement is required in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a tall and thin young girl with slender fingers, dislocated lenses, and cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency is suggestive of classic homocystinuria. The amino acid supplement required in this scenario is cysteine.

Classic homocystinuria is a metabolic disorder of methionine metabolism, due to cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency. It is an autosomal recessive condition.

Cystathionine beta-synthase is a pyridoxal phosphate-dependent enzyme that condenses homocysteine with serine to form cystathionine. The absence of this enzyme will cause cysteine deficiency, hence cysteine needs to be supplemented in the diet.

Clinical features:

  • Affected children are initially asymptomatic. 
  • Ectopia lentis (subluxation of the lens) is seen first, after 3 years of age.
  • Intellectual disability and psychiatric and behavioral disorders.
  • Thromboembolic episodes.
  • Skeletal abnormalities resembling those of Marfan syndrome: They are tall and thin with elongated limbs and arachnodactyly (slender fingers).

Elevations of both methionine and homocysteine in body fluids are the diagnostic laboratory findings. The diagnosis is established by molecular analysis of cystathionine β-synthase (CBS) or by assay of the enzyme in cultured fibroblasts, phytohemagglutinin-stimulated lymphocytes, or liver biopsy specimens. Treatment includes restriction of methionine intake and supplementation with cysteine, betaine, vitamins B6, B12, and folate.

 

The image below shows arachnodactyly. 

 Methionine supplementation is required in non-classical homocystinuria. It is due to impaired re-methylation of homocysteine to methionine. This can be caused by defective methionine synthase or reduced availability of two essential cofactors, 5-methyltetrahydrofolate, and methylcobalamin.

Elevated homocysteine levels with low levels of methionine will be seen. Treatment includes methionine supplementation and administration of methyl folate, hydroxocobalamin, and betaine.

Related Pearl: Homocystinuria

The concept for treatment:

  • Since homocysteine is produced from methionine, decreased dietary intake of methionine decreases the formation of homocysteine.
  • As the end product of this cycle is cysteine, increased dietary intake of cysteine will decrease the conversion of methionine to homocysteine through negative feedback.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with gum bleeding and fever for the past 2 months. General examination showed pallor and the systemic examination was unremarkable. Laboratory examination revealed Hb level- 3 gm/dl, TLC- 1500/microL, platelet count- 15000/microL. Peripheral smear shows macrocytes and the reticulocyte count is 0.5. Bone marrow examination revealed fatty streaks and absent megakaryocytes but no immature cells. What is the likely diagnosis?

Hb- Hemoglobin

TLC- Total leucocyte count
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing a young male with gum bleeding, fever, pancytopenia, and a low reticulocyte count with bone marrow showing fatty streaks and no immature cells is suggestive of idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia.

Aplastic anemia is a syndrome characterized by chronic hematopoietic failure and pancytopenia. The common causes include:

  • Acquired 
    • Idiopathic (most common cause, about 65% of the cases)
    • Acquired stem-cell defects 
    • Immune-mediated
  • Chemical agents 
    • Dose-related (alkylating agents, antimetabolites, benzene, chloramphenicol, inorganic arsenals) 
    • Idiosyncratic (chloramphenicol, phenylbutazone, organic arsenicals, carbamazepine, penicillamine, gold salts) 
  • Physical agents 
    • Whole-body irradiation
    • Viral infections (hepatitis, Cytomegalovirus, Epstein–Barr virus, Varicella-Zoster virus)
  • Inherited 
    • Fanconi anemia 
    • Telomerase defects 

Pathogenesis involves an extrinsic immune-mediated suppression of bone marrow and an intrinsic abnormality of the stem cells. 

Clinical features and diagnosis:

There is no age or sex predisposition for aplastic anemia. It presents insidiously with features of pancytopenia such as pallor, petechiae, and ecchymosis. Recurrent infections and fever occur as a result of neutropenia. Reticulocytopenia is seen and splenomegaly is characteristically absent. Bone marrow biopsy is used for diagnosis.

Histology:

Bone marrow aspirate usually results in a dry tap. Examination shows a hypocellular marrow devoid of hematopoietic cells with remnant fat cells, fibrous stroma, and scattered lymphocytes. Red cells are usually slightly macrocytic and normochromic. The following image shows a hypocellular bone marrow with little hematopoiesis and several fat cells.

Other options: 

Option B - Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is an acquired disorder resulting from the mutation in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A gene (PIGA), an enzyme that is essential for the synthesis of membrane-associated complement regulatory proteins. Red cells deficient in these proteins are susceptible to intravascular hemolysis. Patients with PNH usually present with pancytopenia and reticulocytosis with bone marrow biopsy showing a cellular marrow with marked to massive erythroid hyperplasia.

Option C - Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) are a group of clonal stem cell disorders. It is a consequence of maturation defects that result in ineffective hematopoiesis with a high predisposition to conversion to AML. They are characterized by a hypercellular marrow with dysplastic cells on bone marrow aspirate. Marrow changes seen in MDS are given in the pearl below.

Option D - Pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis and patients often present with fever, productive cough, blood-streaked sputum, night sweats, malaise, loss of appetite, and weight loss.

Related Pearl: Bone Marrow Changes in Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS)

The myelodysplastic syndrome can lead to dysplasia of the erythroid series, myeloid series, and megakaryocytes.

Dysplasia of erythroid series:

  • Megaloblastoid maturation - Abnormally large erythroid cells
  • Nuclear budding abnormalities - Nucleus with abnormal shape
  • Ring sideroblasts - Erythroblasts with stainable iron in the cytoplasm 

 

Dysplasia of myeloid series:

  • Neutrophils with a decreased number of secondary granules
  • Pseudo-Pelger-HuÃàet cells- neutrophils with only two nuclear lobes

 

Dysplasia of the megakaryocytes:

  • Megakaryocyte with single nuclear lobe
  • Pawn ball megakaryocytes- cells with multiple separate nuclei

If only one lineage is affected, then it is called single lineage dysplasia. If multiple lineages are affected, then it is called multilineage dysplasia. If the percentage of ring sideroblasts is more than 15% it is called MDS with ring sideroblasts (MDS-RS).

questions.text: A child is presenting with palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, and pain in the knee joint resulting from arthritis. Urine examination showed hematuria and proteinuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the investigations are suggestive of Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

Henoch-Schönlein purpura is a systemic immune disorder characterized by a purpuric rash, abdominal pain, polyarthralgia, and renal abnormalities. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 3-8 years. The patient may present with the following clinical features:

  • Skin lesions- characteristically involve the extensor surfaces of arms and legs, and also the buttocks
  • Abdominal manifestations- include pain, vomiting, and intestinal bleeding.
  • Renal manifestations- include gross or microscopic hematuria, nephritic syndrome, or nephrotic syndrome. Renal manifestations are more severe in adults. A rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis is seen in some cases.

This condition usually occurs following an upper respiratory tract infection and there is a history of atopy in one-third of the cases. IgA is deposited in the glomerular mesangium in a distribution similar to that of IgA nephropathy.

Microscopic findings:

  • IgA deposition in the mesangial region. Sometimes there is the deposition of IgG and C3 along with IgA.
  • Renal lesions show focal or diffuse mesangial proliferation, and/or endocapillary proliferation to crescentic glomerulonephritis.
  • Skin lesions show subepidermal hemorrhages and necrotizing vasculitis of small vessels.

Other options:

Option A: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura(ITP): It occurs due to antibody-mediated destruction of platelets. It can be acute or chronic. Acute ITP is usually self-limiting in nature. Cutaneous bleeding can be in the form of petechiae and ecchymoses. The patient can also have hematuria, melena, or excessive menstrual flow. 

Option B: Dengue: It is a viral illness caused by the dengue virus. The clinical manifestations include fever, headache, musculoskeletal pain, and rash. The rash which is maculopapular in nature begins on the trunk and then spreads centrifugally to the face and extremities.

Option C: Churg- Strauss syndrome (Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis): It is characterized by eosinophilic vasculitis of multiple organs. The features of this condition include asthma, peripheral eosinophilia, pulmonary infiltrates, neuropathy, paranasal sinus abnormality, and the presence of eosinophilic vasculitis.

questions.text: What formula is the dosing rate of a drug based on?
questions.solution:
The formula for drug dosing rate is clearance x plasma concentration.

The equation for dose rate given here is based on steady-state concentration. When a drug is given repeatedly at short intervals it will accumulate in the body until the elimination of the drug matches its input. So steady-state concentration is the plasma concentration at which the drug elimination and drug input balance each other.

Steady-state concentration(Cpss) = Dose rate / Clearance

From this equation dose rate for a target steady-state plasma concentration is calculated as 

Dose rate = Clearance(CL) x target plasma concentration(Cpss)

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic ear infection presents with fever, headache, vomiting, irritability, and confusion. His CT brain is shown in the image below. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette depicting features of CNS infection (fever, headache, vomiting, and confusion) in a patient with a chronic ear infection and the CT image showing a ring-enhancing lesion point to a diagnosis of a temporal lobe abscess.

Temporal lobe abscess is an intracranial complication that can arise from chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM).

Brain abscess typically progresses through four stages. The first stage is the stage of invasion (initial encephalitis), which often goes unnoticed. Symptoms such as headache, malaise, low-grade fever, and drowsiness may be present.

The second stage is the stage of localization (latent abscess), during which a capsule forms around the abscess, effectively localizing the pus.

The third stage is the stage of enlargement (manifest abscess). The abscess enlarges, leading to increased intracranial pressure (ICP) and the development of edema surrounding the abscess. As a result, symptoms worsen.

The final stage is the stage of termination (rupture of abscess). At this point, the abscess expands and eventually ruptures into the ventricle or subarachnoid space, which can result in potentially fatal meningitis.

Signs of raised ICP may include headache, nausea, vomiting, lethargy, drowsiness, confusion, papilledema, and coma.

Characteristic findings associated with temporal lobe abscess include nominal aphasia, homonymous hemianopia, seizures, contralateral motor paralysis, pupillary changes, and oculomotor palsy.

The preferred diagnostic imaging modality for temporal lobe abscess is a CT scan of the brain. This imaging study reveals a ring-enhancing lesion indicative of a brain abscess.

Medical treatment involves initiating intravenous antibiotics, typically metronidazole. Raised ICP can be addressed using dexamethasone or mannitol.

Surgical intervention is the definitive management and involves drainage of the abscess followed by radical mastoidectomy to address the underlying CSOM.

Other options:

Option B: Cerebellar abscess is a form of brain abscess and is usually associated with an otogenic source of infection. It can occur as a direct extension through Trautmann's triangle or via retrograde thrombophlebitis. 

An MRI image showing cerebellar abscess is given below:

Option C: Subdural abscess refers to the focal collection of purulent material between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater. 

An MRI image showing subdural abscess is given below:

Option D: Meningitis is the inflammation of the leptomeninges which includes the arachnoid mater and pia mater. It can be due to an infectious or noninfectious etiology. It presents with fever, vomiting, neck stiffness, and signs of meningeal irritation. Ring enhancing lesion on neuroimaging is not a feature of meningitis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old married woman who is anxious to conceive presents with copious vaginal discharge, without any itching. Her last menstrual period was 13 days ago. What is the cause of her vaginal discharge?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young woman with copious, non-pruritic (without itching) vaginal discharge occurring 13 days after menstrual period (period of ovulation) is most likely to be leucorrhoea (physiological).

The term leucorrhoea can be used in conditions where normal vaginal secretion is increased in amount. An increase in this normal vaginal secretion develops physiologically:

  • At puberty
  • At ovulation
  • During pregnancy
  • During the premenstrual phase, occasionally

It may be cervical or vaginal in origin. A speculum examination of the vagina can distinguish between the two. If the discharge is cervical in origin, an excessive mucoid discharge will be visible at the external os.

Normal discharge appears clear or white, without any odor or itching, and will have a pH of 3.8-4.2.

Other options:

Option A: Candidiasis is caused by infection with Candida albicans and presents with pruritus, burning, and dysuria with vulvar erythema, edema, and excoriations. A curdy white discharge will be present. 

Option B: Bacterial vaginosis is caused by an alteration in the normal vaginal flora and presents without itching and a malodorous grey-white discharge. It is diagnosed using Amsel's criteria, where at least three of the four following criteria should be present to confirm the diagnosis:

  • Homogenous vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine-like odor on adding KOH (Whiff test positive)
  • Clue cells (>20% of cells)

Option C: Trichomoniasis is caused by Trichomonas vaginalis and presents with a copious, frothy, offensive yellow-green discharge with vaginal soreness or irritation and urinary frequency. On examination, the vagina looks red and inflamed. The inflamed cervix looks like a strawberry with punctate hemorrhagic spots.

questions.text: A patient developed atonic postpartum hemorrhage after a normal vaginal delivery. She was shifted to the OT and the obstetrician planned ligation of vessels to arrest the bleeding. What is the order of ligation of the blood vessels supplying the uterus?

choices.text: Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Internal iliac artery
Uterine artery - Ovarian artery- External iliac artery
Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery
Uterine artery - pudendal artery - Vaginal artery

questions.solution:
The order of ligation of vessels to arrest bleeding in atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) is the uterine artery - ovarian artery - internal iliac artery.

The ascending branch of the uterine artery is ligated between the upper and lower segments of the uterus, at the lateral border. If the bleeding continues, the ovarian and uterine artery anastomosis is ligated just below the ovarian ligament. If the bleeding still persists, the anterior division of the internal iliac artery is ligated 5 cm distal to the common iliac bifurcation.  

Unilateral or bilateral ligation of the internal iliac artery ligation causes a reduction in the pulse pres­sure in the arteries distal to the ligation. This increases the chances of hemostasis via pressure and clot formation.

Surgical methods to control PPH are outlined as stepwise uterine devascularization procedures:

  • Compression sutures: B-Lynch suture
  • Ligation of uterine arteries
  • Ligation of ovarian and uterine anastomosis
  • Ligation of internal iliac artery
  • Angiographic embolization of the bleeding vessel

Pelvic packing (usually done prior to embolization) and hysterectomy are other surgical methods employed to control PPH.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the post mortem change shown in the image given below?

choices.text: Due to sulphemoglobin accumulation and formation
Due to aseptic non bacterial cause
It is associated with a case of lightning

questions.solution:
The postmortem change shown in the given image is marbling. It is seen when blood in the vessels is haemolysed to sulfmeth-hemoglobin, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance.

Marbling:

The marbling of the skin begins at about 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36–48 hours after death. It is a visible postmortem change that is characterized by linear branching patterns on skin that correspond to the course of superficial veins. Intestinal bacteria infest the venous system and there is subsequent gas production and hemolysis which stains the vessel walls. This becomes prominent in the summer and is distinctly appreciable in the superficial veins of the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

Lichtenberg's figures or filigree burns are pathognomonic for lightning injury. It is a superficial, thin, tortuous, fern-like pattern of erythema in the skin. It indicates the path taken by the electrical discharge and tends to follow skin creases and the long axis of the body. They are also known as arborescent burns or feathering as they have a resemblance to the branches of a tree. Lichtenberg's figures occur due to the rupture of small vessels. They are usually seen over the shoulder or flank within an hour of injury and disappear in 1-2 days.

Medico-legal aspect: Its recognition may be lifesaving in the unaccompanied comatose patient and is important because even delayed resuscitation of lightning victims can be very successful.

The image below shows the filigree burns seen in a case of lightning.

questions.text: What is the most common complication associated with the following abnormality?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a coloboma of the upper eyelid. The most common complication associated with this condition is exposure keratopathy since the defect leaves the cornea exposed. If left untreated, it can lead to corneal ulceration.

Coloboma of the eyelid is a partial or full-thickness eyelid defect. It usually occurs near the nasal side. It more frequently involves the upper lid than the lower lid. It occurs when eyelid development is incomplete, due to failure of migration of lid ectoderm to fuse with the lid folds.

Small defects can be managed by primary closure, while large defects require skin grafts and rotation flaps.

Upper lid colobomas occur at the junction of the middle and inner thirds. It has a relatively strong association with cryptophthalmos, facial abnormalities, and Goldenhar syndrome. Cryptophthalmos is a congenital anomaly in which the eyelids are absent, replaced by a continuous layer of skin.

Lower lid colobomas occur at the junction of the middle and outer thirds and are frequently associated with systemic conditions.

Treacher Collins syndrome (mandibulofacial dysostosis) is a genetically heterogeneous condition. It is characterized by mandibular and ear anomalies. lower eyelid coloboma, slanted palpebral apertures, cataract, microphthalmos, and lacrimal atresia.

questions.text: A patient on digoxin, potassium chloride, clarithromycin, atenolol, and triamterene developed atrial fibrillation with controlled ventricular rate. Serum digoxin levels were raised. Which of his medications is responsible for the same?
questions.solution:
Elevated serum digoxin levels and the development of atrial fibrillation with controlled ventricular rate are suggestive of digoxin toxicity. Clarithromycin when given along with digoxin can cause digoxin toxicity.

P-glycoprotein pumps play a major role in the elimination of digoxin. Drugs that inhibit P-glycoprotein can thereby decrease the elimination of digoxin and lead to digoxin toxicity. Macrolide antibiotics like clarithromycin and erythromycin are inhibitors of the P-glycoprotein. So clarithromycin when given along with digoxin can cause digoxin toxicity.

Other drugs that inhibit P-glycoprotein are - Amiodarone, quinidine, verapamil, diltiazem, cyclosporine, itraconazole, propafenone, and flecainide.

Digoxin is one of the cardiac glycosides which is derived from the digitalis plant and used clinically.

It inhibits Na+/K+ ATPase, a membrane-bound transporter to increase intracellular sodium. As a result, there is less expulsion of calcium from the cell by sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX). Increased calcium inside the myocyte leads to an increase in cardiac contractility.

The most common cardiac manifestations of digitalis toxicity include atrioventricular junctional rhythm, premature ventricular depolarizations, ventricular bigeminy, ventricular tachycardia, and second-degree AV blockade.

Factors that increase the risk of digoxin toxicity are:

  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypokalemia- It increases the binding of the digoxin to the Na+/K+ ATPase pump. 
  • Drugs causing hypokalemia- loop and thiazide diuretics, amphotericin B, corticosteroids
  • Drugs that decrease digoxin elimination (inhibitors of P-glycoprotein)
  • Renal failure
  • Hypothyroidism

 Triamterene, atenolol, and potassium chloride cause hyperkalemia, and therefore do not cause digoxin toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following interleukin (IL) is inhibited by tocilizumab?
questions.solution:
Tocilizumab inhibits IL-6.

Tocilizumab is a newer humanized antibody. It binds to the soluble, membrane-bound IL-6 receptors and inhibits IL-6 mediated signaling. IL-6 can cause T-cell activation, acute-phase protein synthesis, and stimulation of inflammatory processes in diseases like rheumatoid arthritis.

Uses:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis - It is a biological DMARD and is indicated in adult patients having moderate to severe disease with inadequate response to one or more DMARDs.
  • Juvenile idiopathic arthritis - It can be given for active systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis(SJIA) or polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis(PJIA) in patients of 2 years of age or more.

Adverse effects:

Common adverse effects include upper respiratory infections, hypertension, headache, and elevation of hepatic enzymes. It is also associated with serious infections including TB and opportunistic infections. Neutropenia and reduction in platelet count can also occur.

Other options:

Option B- IL-2 receptor inhibitors are daclizumab, basiliximab. They are used as immunosuppressive agents following renal and heart transplants.

Option C- IL-4 receptor inhibitor is dupilumab. They have been shown to reduce exacerbations in asthma. 

Option D- IL-5 inhibitors are mepolizumab, reslizumab, benralizumab. They have been shown to reduce exacerbations in asthma. 

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and¬†in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital with complaints of pain around the left hip joint following a road traffic accident. On examination, the affected limb was flexed, adducted, and medially rotated with obvious shortening. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing a flexed, adducted, and medially rotated limb with apparent limb shortening following trauma is suggestive of posterior hip dislocation.

Posterior hip dislocation is the most common type of hip dislocation commonly seen following dashboard injuries. 

X-ray findings:

  • Upward dislocation of the femoral head
  • Femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • Lesser trochanter is not visualized as the thigh is internally rotated
  • Femoral head and posterior acetabular wall fractures may also be seen.

Treatment: Early reduction should be done as the risk of osteonecrosis and subsequent osteoarthritis increases with time. 

Closed reduction under sedation or general anesthesia is done in most cases. Closed reduction should not be attempted in associated femoral neck fractures as it can lead to the displacement of the femoral neck and disrupt the blood supply to the femoral head.

If there is a failure of closed reduction or any significant fractures then surgical repair should be done. If there is a delay in surgical correction skeletal traction with a distal femoral traction pin can be done.

Early complications include sciatic nerve injury, vascular injury (superior gluteal artery tear can occur), and concurrent femoral shaft fracture (when both occur together hip dislocation may be missed).

Late complications include osteonecrosis of the femoral head, myositis ossificans, secondary osteoarthritis, and recurrent instability.

The image given below shows posterior hip dislocation on the left side.

Other options:

Option A: Anterior hip dislocations are less common than posterior hip dislocations. This injury is usually sustained following a high-energy accident. The affected limb will be abducted, externally rotated, and slightly flexed.

Option C: Transcervical fracture is a type of fracture neck of the femur where the fracture line is in the middle of the neck. In this case, there can be shortening and external rotation of the affected limb.

Option D: Intertrochanteric fracture is usually sustained following a fall or road traffic accident. The leg is short and externally rotated. Clinical findings are more marked than the neck of femur fractures.

questions.text: A pregnant woman whose niece lives with her in the same house contracted Varicella. She tested negative for serum antibodies against varicella. What would this mean?

choices.text: She is susceptible to chicken pox
She is immune to chicken pox

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing the absence of serum antibodies is indicative of susceptibility to chickenpox.

Varicella zoster virus causes two host responses which present as chickenpox and herpes zoster. They are characterized by a vesicular rash that is accompanied by fever and malaise (chickenpox). The immune system eliminates the infection except for some virions that establish latent infections inside nerve cells which are reactivated when immunity is compromised and present as herpes zoster.

One attack with the virus gives durable immunity while a second attack of the virus is rare. In the absence of immunity, all ages are equally susceptible to the disease. The acquisition of maternal antibodies protects the infant during the first few months of life. The IgG antibodies produced during the first attack with the virus persist for life and their presence is correlated with protection against varicella. The absence of antibodies in the given scenario signifies that the patient is susceptible to chicken pox. Hence, the serologic screening of serum for lgG antibodies is used to assess immunity or susceptibility of a person to varicella, especially in unvaccinated people, e.g. in healthcare workers.

The presence of cell-mediated immunity appears to be important in the recovery from VZ infections and in protection against the reactivation of latent VZ virus which causes Herpes zoster.¬†

Varicella in pregnant women :

The contraction of the virus by a pregnant woman increases the risk of the fetus to congenital varicella syndrome. This is seen in mothers who are affected during the first 20 weeks of gestation. Affected babies present with the following :

  • Foetal wastage
  • Cutaneous scars
  • Atrophied limbs
  • Microcephaly
  • Low birth weight
  • Cataract
  • Microphthalmia
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Deafness
  • Cerebra-cortical atrophy

Prevention:

  • Varicella-Zoster lmmunoglobulin (VZIG) is given as post-exposure prophylaxis within 72 hours of exposure and has been recommended for prevention of chickenpox in exposed susceptible individuals particularly in immunosuppressed persons such as:
    • Persons receiving immunosuppressive therapy
    • Persons with congenital cellular immunodeficiency
    • Persons with acquired immunodeficiency including HIV/AIDS
    • Exposed pregnant women
    • Newborns
    • Premature infants of low birth weight
  • Live attenuated vaccine is administered to children who have not had chicken pox between the age of 12 to 18 months.

questions.text:
What is the mechanism of action of methotrexate in osteosarcoma?

UMP- Uridine monophosphate

DHFR-¬†Dihydrofolate reductase
questions.solution:
The anticancer activity of methotrexate is by inhibition of¬†dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR).

Methotrexate belongs to the antimetabolite class of anticancer drugs. The antifolate action of the drug is responsible for its anti-cancer properties.

Mechanism of action:

It is a folic acid analog and binds to the active catalytic site of¬†dihydrofolate reductase(DHFR). This would inhibit the formation of tetrahydrofolate(THF)¬†which is needed for purine nucleotides, thymidylate, and the amino acids serine and methionine. This would interfere with the production of DNA, RNA, and important cellular proteins.

Low doses of methotrexate are used in the management of rheumatic diseases. It is due to the inhibition of¬†amino-imidazole carboxamide ribonucleotide (AICAR) transformylase and thymidylate synthetase. This results in increased levels of adenosine that inhibits inflammation.

Adverse effects:

Common side effects are nausea and mucosal ulcers. Others include anemia, leukopenia, stomatitis, GI ulcerations, and alopecia. Dose-related hepatotoxicity is also seen. The GI effects and hepatotoxicity can be reduced by the use of leucovorin or folinic acid.¬†

questions.text: A patient presented with joint pain and on evaluation, urine turns black on standing. What is the likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The urine turning black in color, on exposure to air, along with joint pain is suggestive of alkaptonuria. It occurs due to the defect in the homogentisic acid 1, 2 - dioxygenase enzyme.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase/homogentisic acid 1, 2 - dioxygenase, which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate. The defect in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of homogentisate, which is then excreted in the urine. 

Alkaptonuria is characterized by homogentisic aciduria, ochronosis, and arthropathy (joint pain).

Homogentisic aciduria is the black discoloration of urine on prolonged exposure to air caused due to oxidation of the excreted homogentisate. 

Ochronosis is the accumulation of oxidized homogentisic acid pigment (alkaptone bodies) in connective tissues leading to bluish-black discoloration of tissues mostly involving ear cartilage, ocular tissue, the skin of the eyelids, forehead, cheeks, and hands, nail beds, and intervertebral discs. The compound that accumulates in the tissues in ochronosis is benzoquinone acetate.

Painful arthritis (arthropathy) may be seen from the fourth or fifth decade.

Diagnosis: Blackish discoloration of urine on standing is diagnostic of alkaptonuria (shown below). The ferric chloride test will be positive.

The image further below shows Ochronosis. 

 

Treatment:  No specific treatment is required. Symptomatic treatment with analgesics, spinal surgery, and arthroplasty along with ascorbic acid and protein restriction can be considered. Nitisinone (p-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid (pHPPA) oxidase inhibitor) reduces urinary excretion of homogentisic acid.

Other options:

Option B: Tyrosine transaminase deficiency causes type II tyrosinemia (Richner-Hanhart syndrome). Patients present with painful corneal erosions with photophobia, learning disability, and palmoplantar keratosis.

Option C: Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase deficiency causes type I tyrosinemia (Tyrosinosis). Patients generally present with failure to thrive, neuropathy, boiled-cabbage urine, and liver failure secondary to cirrhosis.

Option D:  4-hydroxy-phenyl pyruvate dioxygenase deficiency causes type III tyrosinemia (neonatal tyrosinemia). Patients might rarely have a mental disability. The liver function is generally normal.

questions.text:
A patient following a skid resulting in a motor traffic accident was brought to the emergency room 2 hours later. On examination, he was stable with GCS 15/15. The pupil was reactive to light. Tenderness and bruising over the left lower chest wall with petechiae was seen. Severe tenderness was elicited in the left hypochondriac region and BP- 90/50 mm of Hg. What is the best investigation used in the ER?

GCS- Glasgow coma scale¬†

FAST- Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma
questions.solution:
FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) is the best investigation that can be performed in the emergency room (ER) for this patient with a blood pressure of 90/50 mm Hg who has sustained blunt abdominal trauma.¬†

Focussed assessment with sonography for trauma¬†is a non-invasive investigation that can be performed rapidly in the emergency room. It helps in identifying an abnormal collection of fluid or blood. FAST is indicated in:

  • Haemodynamically unstable patients who had a blunt abdominal trauma
  • Patients who sustained penetrating abdominal trauma with no other indications for immediate laparotomy (signs of haemodynamic instability, peritoneal irritation, peritoneal penetration and gunshot wound with transperitoneal trajectory).

FAST includes an examination of four regions:¬†

  • Pericardial sac
  • Hepatorenal fossa
  • Splenorenal fossa, and
  • Pouch of Douglas

It is an operator-dependent procedure with limited visualization of the retroperitoneal structures.¬†

Other options:

Option B - A chest¬†X-Ray is used to exclude hemothorax or pneumothorax¬†in a¬†hemodynamically normal patient with penetrating trauma above the umbilicus or a suspected thoracoabdominal injury.¬†Since the given patient is alert, awake, and with no mention of any pelvic pain or tenderness, a pelvic X-Ray is not indicated either.¬†

Option C - Diagnostic peritoneal lavage¬†is an invasive procedure and requires surgical expertise. For these reasons, it is done only in centres where FAST and/ CT are not available.

Option D - CT scan¬†requires transporting the patient and is time-consuming. Hence, it cannot be performed in the ER in a haemodynamically unstable patient.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents to you with inflammatory alopecia. Which of the following variants of tinea capitis infection commonly result in this type of alopecia?
questions.solution:
Favus and kerion are the inflammatory variants of tinea capitis.

Tinea capitis is a dermatophyte infection primarily occurring in children. Clinical features of tinea capitis are patchy hair loss, scaling, tender lymphadenopathy, and in severe cases, there might be pustules and crusting of the affected area along with sinus formation. 

The clinical variants of tinea capitis are:

  • Kerion is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis which presents with an inflammatory mass with thick crusting and matting of hair.
  • Favus is characterized by the presence of yellowish, cup‚Äêshaped crusts known as scutula that develop around hair follicles.
  • Endothrix is a non inflammatory type in which black dots form around swollen hair shafts.
  • Ectothrix is a mild inflammatory type in which dull grey coated broken hairs is seen.

questions.text: A teenage patient presented with a history of dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain. On ultrasonography, a transverse vaginal septum was seen. What is the most common complication that can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most common complication that can be seen in this patient is endometriosis.

Transverse vaginal septum leads to obstructed flow of menstrual blood. This may lead to retrograde menstruation, which increases the likelihood of the development of endometriosis, according to Sampson's theory of endometriosis.

Transverse vaginal septum occurs as a result of the failure of M√ºllerian duct fusion or failure of¬†vaginal plate canalization. It may be obstructive or non-obstructive.¬†The commonest site of a transverse septum is the junction between the upper and middle third of the vagina.

Patients with an obstructive or imperforate vaginal septum present with symptoms similar to the imperforate hymen. Symptoms include amenorrhoea, cyclical abdominal pain, urinary symptoms, and a palpable pelvic mass. The vagina may appear shortened and the cervix may not be identifiable. Secondary sexual characteristics appear normal. The diagnosis can be confirmed with ultrasound or MRI.

There is an increased¬†risk of endometriosis.¬†Other complications such as pyomucocolpos, pyometra, and pyosalpinges can also develop in infants with obstructive vaginal septums.¬†

Treatment is by manual dilatation of the perforation or surgical excision of the septum.¬†

Other options:

Option B: Tubo-ovarian abscess¬†develops in pelvic¬†inflammatory disease.

Option C: Dermoid cysts are cystic ovarian tumors that are often associated with mucinous cystadenomas.

Option D: Theca lutein cysts are¬†found in association with hydatidiform moles, choriocarcinoma, and gonadotropin or clomiphene citrate therapy. They regress with the management of the mole and choriocarcinoma and discontinuation of gonadotropin therapy.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with fatigue, tiredness and cervical lymphadenopathy. The TLC and DLC were normal. No immature cells. A lymph node biopsy was performed which shows diffuse effacement of the lymph node architecture, cells with an indented nucleus, prominent nucleolus, and are atypical. CD10 and BCL2 are positive. What is the likely diagnosis?

TLC- Total leucocyte count

DLC- Differential leucocyte count
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing fatigue, tiredness and cervical lymphadenopathy with CD10 positive BCL2 positive cells is highly suggestive of follicular lymphoma.

Follicular lymphoma presents at middle age with no sex predilection. The most common presenting symptom is painless generalized lymphadenopathy. A lymph node biopsy is adequate for the diagnosis of follicular lymphoma. Immunophenotyping of the cells showing CD19, CD20, CD10, BCL2 positive, and CD5 negative is suggestive that the cells originate from the germinal centre. 

The majority of follicular lymphomas have characteristic (14;18) translocation. This juxtaposes the IGH locus on chromosome 14 and the BCL2 locus on chromosome 18. This chromosomal rearrangement results in the overexpression of BCL2 protein, which is an inhibitor of apoptosis that contributes to lymphoma cell survival.

Histopathology:

Lymph nodes exhibit a nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern. Two cell types are predominantly present in varying proportions: 

  • Centrocytes (small cleaved cells) - Small cells with a cleaved nucleus and scant cytoplasm
  • Centroblasts - Large cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm

In most cases, there is a majority of centrocytes.

The peripheral blood smear shows lymphocytosis and bone marrow tap reveals paratrabecular lymphoid aggregates.

The following image shows a lymph node biopsy in follicular lymphoma:

Other options - 

Option B - Burkitt lymphoma is an aggressive type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL). It is also known as small non-cleaved-cell lymphoma and is characterized by the translocation and deregulation of the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8 to chromosome 14 or 22 - t(8:14) or t(8:22). Histopathology of the tumor reveals a starry sky appearance created by apoptotic cells and macrophages containing clear cytoplasm.

Option C - Mycosis fungoides is the most common type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. The histological hallmark of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (mycosis fungoides type) is the presence of Pautrier microabscess. The presence of B-cell markers in the question rules out the differential of mycosis fungoides.

Option D - Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by the presence of chimeric BCR-ABL gene which is a result of a reciprocal (9;22)(q34;q11) translocation (Philadelphia chromosome). The presence of lymphadenopathy in the given scenario rules out the possibility of CML as it is a myeloid disorder.

questions.text: The school health programs are managed by which of the following?
questions.solution:
The school health programs are managed by the primary health centre (PHC).

The School Health Committee (1961) in India recommended that the school health services should be a part of the general health services. Since the general health services are administered through PHCs, school health programs are also managed by the PHCs under their jurisdiction.

The School Health Committee advocated the formation of school health committees at the village level, block level, district level, state level, and national level. The National School Health Council will be an advisory and coordinating body.

PHCs provide the following school health services:

  • Screening of general health assessment of anemia/nutritional status, visual acuity, hearing problem, dental check-up, physical disabilities, learning disorders, and behavior problems, etc.
  • Basic medicines for common ailments
  • Immunization¬†
  • Micronutrient (Vitamin A, iron, and folic acid) management
  • Deworming¬†
  • Mid-day meal

¬†Note: National Programme for Mid-Day Meal in Schools has recently been renamed Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman (PM POSHAN).¬†¬†
